newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Australian Broadcasting Corp Afternoon Update.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Australian Broadcasting Corp Afternoon Update.

text.p: REACTION TO EUTHANASIA DEATH
A monstrous step and a landmark are among polarised reactions to the world's first termination of life under voluntary euthanasia law, with the death of a man under Northern Territory legislation.
Darwin doctor Philip Nitschke ended the 66 year old cancer suffer's life last Sunday with a lethal injection he had requested.
Doctor Nitschke has read a letter from the man asking what right anyone has to demand he live by their rules just because of their religious faith.
And Victorian Premier, Jeff Kennett, says giving people the right to die with grace and dignity is beautiful.
But Deputy Prime Minister Tim Fischer says there's enough culture of death in the world without taking what he calls this monstrous step to euthanasia.
Federal Liberal MP, Kevin Andrews' bill to overturn the Northern Territory law is expected to be debated next month.
ABORIGINE HOME OWNERSHIP RATE LOWER THAN AVERAGE - SURVEY
A bureau of Statistics survey of aboriginal housing has found that most indigenous households rent their homes, with the home ownership rate much lower than for non-aborigines.
Released today, the survey shows an estimated 20 percent of private dwellings were described as not meeting the needs of indigenous households.
That compares with three percent for non aboriginal households.
The most common complaints of indigenous tenants were that properties were in need of repairs, and had a shortage of bedrooms and living space.
SYDNEY MIGRATION AGENCY FACES INVESTIGATION
The Federal police are expected to investigate a Sydney migration agency which demanded huge fees from migrants to help arrange permanent residency.
Nineteen Hong Kong and Chinese migrants have won a Federal Court action allowing them to recover the 20,000 dollars or so they each paid to North-West Immigration Services.
Justice Graham Hill found the company often didn't do anything to assist the migrants get permanent residency.
The Public Interest Advocacy Centre says it will prepare a brief for the Federal police so they can take action against the company and its principal employee Leslie William Alexander.
INQUIRY HEARS OF NEAR CLASH AFTER CRASH
A military inquiry in Perth has heard how two Blackhawk helicopters flew within metres of each other moments after two other aircraft collided and crashed to the ground.
The inquiry is hearing evidence from eye witnesses to the high risk counter-terrorists exercise in Townsville in June in which 18 servicemen were killed.
A soldier who was in one of two sniper helicopters told the inquiry another Black Hawk passed directly below his aircraft which was in a hover.
He said he didn't believe it came dangerously close, but he was concerned about the distance between the two.
He said directly after this, his helicopter landed to help to evacuate the injured from the wreckage of the two crashed aircraft.
BATTLE OVER HANCOCK FORTUNE CONTINUES
The family battle for control of the riches of the late mining magnate Lang Hancock is being argued in the Supreme Court in Perth today.
Mr Hancock's widow, Rose Porteous, has gone to Court to try to wrest some control of the Hancock companies from the late magnate's daughter Gina Reinhart.
In Court today, Mrs Reinhart's lawyers sought to have her step mother's claim struck out, describing parts of it as fundamentally flawed, embarrassing and vague.
Neither of the Hancock women are in Court today. However, Mrs Porteous' husband is monitoring proceedings.
The case is continuing.
TITANIC SURVIVOR'S FUNERAL
There's been a funeral service for the last Adelaide survivor of the Titanic disaster.

96-year-old Thomas Bell, who died last Friday, was a cabin boy aboard the liner, when it sank on its maiden voyage in 1912. Mr Bell's funeral service has been held at Saint Albans Anglican Church at Largs Bay.
A representative of the Titanic and Steamship Historical Society says that Mr Bell had supported the recent salvage work on the wreck of the Titanic.
ABC METROS TO LOSE PRESENTERS
ABC metropolitan radio stations will lose at least one of their morning presenters as part of a shake-up prompted by Federal Government funding cuts.
From next year, the two shows that now run between 8-30 and Midday on metropolitan stations will become one program and the early afternoon program will be transformed into a statewide broadcast.
The final on-air line-ups have yet to be finalised, with ABC Management saying no committments have been made to any of the presenters affected by the changes.
Metropolitan and regional stations will lose around 63 jobs nationwide as a result of the restructure.
The ABC's Board has also decided to either axe or merge a number of Radio National programs, including religious, arts, education and science shows.

ABC Managers have told a Senate committee in Canberra a total of 900 positions were likely to be cut over the next two financial years because of the funding shortfall...that's just under 20 per-cent of the Corporation's current workforce.
